tasks: As an Explorer, you should create a list of 5 common pain points in your current projects, using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework. Document each pain point with 2 possible solutions and rate their feasibility (1-5) on a scale from 'not feasible' to 'very feasible'. This will help you better understand user needs and identify areas for improvement in Product Thinking & Strategy (Reference: Conducting User Research).

Create a mind map of the 8-point grid system, illustrating how it can be applied to your portfolio's navigation. Focus on visualizing the relationships between elements and identifying potential improvements. This will help you better understand UI Craft & Visual Design principles (Reference: Tesler’s Law).

Design a simple wireframe for a hypothetical product feature using Hick’s Law as a guide. Ensure that the user can complete the task in 2-3 steps, with minimal cognitive load. This will help you apply UX Fundamentals principles to real-world design challenges.

Conduct 1 user interview and document 3 pain points using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework. Analyze your findings and identify potential solutions that align with Product Thinking & Strategy principles (Reference: Laws of UX).

Redesign a existing product's navigation using the 8-point grid system, focusing on visual hierarchy and information architecture. This will help you apply UI Craft & Visual Design principles to real-world design challenges.

Create a list of 3 common usability heuristics that are often overlooked in design. Provide examples of how these heuristics can be applied to improve user experience (Reference: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design).

Create a case study of a successful product redesign that incorporates Product Thinking & Strategy principles. Analyze the design decisions and identify key takeaways for improving your own work (Reference: Laws of UX).

Design a prototype of a hypothetical feature using Aesthetic-Usability Effect as a guide. Ensure that the design is visually appealing and easy to use. This will help you apply UX Fundamentals principles to real-world design challenges.
Write a short reflection on your own collaboration style, identifying areas for improvement in Communication & Collaboration (Reference: Tesler’s Law).

Develop a comprehensive Product Thinking & Strategy plan for a hypothetical product feature. Include user research findings, design decisions, and key performance indicators (KPIs) to measure success.

Create a visual design system that incorporates the 8-point grid system and Hick’s Law principles. Document your design decisions and provide examples of how this system can be applied to real-world projects.
Conduct a peer review of your own portfolio, providing constructive feedback on UI Craft & Visual Design principles (Reference: Tesler’s Law).

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the power to shape the user experience of products and services that impact people's lives. To unlock your full potential, focus on developing a strong foundation in UX fundamentals, UI craft, and collaboration - with a goal of consistently delivering high-quality designs that meet users' needs.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick's Law and its Impact on UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to design intuitive navigation and minimize cognitive load.
practice_points: Create a wireframe of a website with 5-7 navigation options and calculate the time it takes for users to complete a task using Hick's Law (max 30 minutes).
Conduct an A/B test on a existing website to see how changing the number of navigation options affects user completion rates. Document findings.
Design a new navigation system for a hypothetical e-commerce website, applying Hick's Law principles to minimize cognitive load.

topics.name: Aesthetic-Usability Effect: Designing for Visual Hierarchy
topics.summary: Creating an effective visual hierarchy that guides user attention and improves usability.
practice_points: Create 3 wireframes of a product page with varying levels of emphasis on key features, applying the Aesthetic-Usability Effect. Document design decisions.
Conduct a usability study on a existing website to identify areas where the visual hierarchy is effective or ineffective. Provide recommendations for improvement.
Design a new logo and branding system that incorporates the Aesthetic-Usability Effect to create a clear visual hierarchy.

topics.name: Tesler’s Law: Designing for Readability
topics.summary: Applying Tesler's Law to improve the readability of text on screens.
practice_points: Create a before-and-after design comparison of a paragraph of text with varying levels of formatting, applying Tesler’s Law. Document findings.
Conduct an A/B test on a existing website or app to see how changing font size and line spacing affects readability. Document results.
Design a new typography system for a hypothetical blog platform, incorporating Tesler's Law principles to improve readability.

insights.brief: Scores indicate a need for improvement in understanding user needs and behaviors.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not fully comprehend user behavior, leading to potential design decisions that don't meet user expectations. Additionally, there might be gaps in knowledge about human-centered design principles and best practices in UX fundamentals.
actionable: Take a course or attend workshops on UX fundamentals to improve understanding of user needs and behaviors.
Study successful designs and analyze what makes them effective in terms of user experience.
Join online communities or forums focused on UX design to stay updated with industry trends and best practices.

insights.brief: Scores indicate a need for improvement in creating visually appealing and user-friendly interfaces.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer has some skills but may not fully understand how to create UI elements that are both aesthetically pleasing and functional. There might be room for improvement in terms of color theory, typography, or composition.
actionable: Study design principles such as balance, contrast, and alignment to improve visual design skills.
Practice creating wireframes and prototypes using design tools like Sketch, Figma, or Adobe XD.
Analyze successful designs in the UI Craft & Visual Design category to understand what makes them effective.

insights.brief: Scores indicate a need for improvement in conducting user research and validating design decisions.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer may not fully understand how to conduct user interviews, usability testing, or A/B testing effectively. There might be gaps in knowledge about how to analyze and act on user feedback.
actionable: Take a course or attend workshops on user research methods such as user interviews, usability testing, and A/B testing.
Practice conducting user research using online resources or working with a mentor.
Study successful design decisions that were informed by user research to understand how it can be applied effectively.

insights.brief: Scores indicate a need for improvement in understanding product development and strategy.
insights.detailed: The low score suggests that the designer may not fully comprehend how products are developed, launched, and maintained. There might be gaps in knowledge about product management principles, market trends, or competitor analysis.
actionable: Take a course or attend workshops on product thinking and strategy to improve understanding of product development and launch processes.
Study successful product launches and analyze what makes them effective in terms of user experience and business goals.
Join online communities or forums focused on product management to stay updated with industry trends and best practices.

insights.brief: Scores indicate a need for improvement in collaborating effectively with team members and communicating design decisions.
insights.detailed: The moderate score suggests that the designer may not fully understand how to collaborate with cross-functional teams or communicate complex design concepts clearly. There might be gaps in knowledge about project management tools, stakeholder management, or conflict resolution.
actionable: Take a course or attend workshops on collaboration and communication skills to improve working relationships with team members.
Practice communicating design decisions using clear and concise language, and learn to use project management tools effectively.
Study successful design teams and analyze how they collaborate and communicate to achieve their goals.
